body_html:
The shape functions run during graph construction, not execution - as a means to catch shape errors as early as possible. The value of input tensors is not available (because it hasn't been computed), and thus the shape functions cannot always infer a fully-specified shape.

You'll see this for example in ops like Unique, where the operation would have to be computed in order to get the fully-specified shape.

If I understand your operation correctly, you'd have to do something like:

output = c->MakeShape({c->Dim(dims2, 2), InferenceContext::kUnknownDim});

Hope that helps.
body_text:
The shape functions run during graph construction, not execution - as a means to catch shape errors as early as possible. The value of input tensors is not available (because it hasn't been computed), and thus the shape functions cannot always infer a fully-specified shape.
You'll see this for example in ops like Unique, where the operation would have to be computed in order to get the fully-specified shape.
If I understand your operation correctly, you'd have to do something like:
output = c->MakeShape({c->Dim(dims2, 2), InferenceContext::kUnknownDim});
Hope that helps.
body:
The shape functions run during graph construction, not execution - as a means to catch shape errors as early as possible. The value of input tensors is not available (because it hasn't been computed), and thus the shape functions cannot always infer a fully-specified shape.

You'll see this for example in [ops like `Unique`](https://github.com/tensorflow/tensorflow/blob/abd64d680b9afa37e8c0a7ce5504c1f7c1a81fbc/tensorflow/core/ops/array_ops.cc#L1362), where the operation would have to be computed in order to get the fully-specified shape.

If I understand your operation correctly, you'd have to do something like:

```c++
output = c->MakeShape({c->Dim(dims2, 2), InferenceContext::kUnknownDim});
```

Hope that helps.
